case_name: Proprietor of Cottage Industries v. Food Inspector, Thana Borough Municipality

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 155 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 155 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment order dated July 23, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment order dated July 23, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment order dated July 23, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1959. J. Umrigar, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 27, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay allowing the appeal filed by respondent No. 1 against the acquittal of the appellant by the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Thana, and conv

facts.text: Appellant is the proprietor of a shop at Thana known as the Cottage Industries and is a dealer in butter.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the proprietor of a shop at Thana known as the Cottage Industries. He is a dealer in butter. On June 27, 1957, the Food Inspector of the Than Borough Municipality visited the shop of the appellant and purchased from him some quantity of Khandeshi butter.

facts.text: On June 27, 1957, the Food Inspector of the Thana Borough Municipality visited the shop of the appellant and purchased some quantity of Khandeshi butter.

anchor.surface_text: On June 27, 1957, the Food Inspector of the Than Borough Municipality visited the shop of the appellant and purchased from him some quantity of Khandeshi butter. After purchasing the butter, the Food Inspector notified his intention to the appellant that he was going to get the butter analysed.

facts.text: Food Inspector notified intention to the appellant that he was going to get the butter analysed.

anchor.surface_text: After purchasing the butter, the Food Inspector notified his intention to the appellant that he was going to get the butter analysed. He divided the butter into three equal parts, put them in three separate bottles and duly sealed the bottles in the presence of two panchas.

facts.text: Food Inspector divided the butter into three equal parts, put them in three separate bottles and duly sealed the bottles in the presence of two panchas.

anchor.surface_text: He divided the butter into three equal parts, put them in three separate bottles and duly sealed the bottles in the presence of two panchas. He gave one of those bottles to the appellant, sent one to the Public Analyst and kept the third with himself.

facts.text: Food Inspector gave one bottle to the appellant, sent one to the Public Analyst and kept the third with himself.

anchor.surface_text: He gave one of those bottles to the appellant, sent one to the Public Analyst and kept the third with himself. The appellant signed the labels on the bottles and also passed a receipt in favour of the Food Inspector in token of the receipt of one of the bottles and that receipt was signed by the appellant and counter-signed by two panch witnesses.

facts.text: Appellant signed the labels on the bottles and passed a receipt in favour of the Food Inspector, which was counter-signed by two panch witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant signed the labels on the bottles and also passed a receipt in favour of the Food Inspector in token of the receipt of one of the bottles and that receipt was signed by the appellant and counter-signed by two panch witnesses. The Public Analyst analysed the butter sent to him and, sent his report in due course.

facts.text: Public Analyst report stated that the butter contained 18.32 foreign fat, 19.57 moisture and 64.67 milk fat.

anchor.surface_text: In the report it was stated that the butter contained 18.32 foreign fat, 19.57 moisture and 64.67 milk fat. On October 5, 1957, the Food Inspector filed a complaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Than, against the appellant.

facts.text: On October 5, 1957, Food Inspector filed a complaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Thana, against the appellant alleging butter adulterated u/s 2(i)(a) and offence u/s 16 r/w s.7(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On October 5, 1957, the Food Inspector filed a complaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Than, against the appellant. It was alleged therein that the said butter was found to be adulterated as defined in s. 2(i)(a) of the Act and that the appellant had committed an offence under s. 16 of the Act by selling the adulterated article of food in contravention of s. 7(1) of the Act and the rules made thereunder.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Thana acquitted the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Magistrate acquitted the appellant on the ground that it had not been proved beyond reasonable doubt that the butter which was purchased from the shop of the appellant was the very same butter which was sent to the Public Analyst and also for the reason that butter prepared out of curd did not come within the mischief of the definition of the word butter in rule A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955 hereinafter called the Rules.

facts.text: Magistrate acquitted because not proved beyond doubt that butter purchased was same sent to Public Analyst.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Magistrate acquitted the appellant on the ground that it had not been proved beyond reasonable doubt that the butter which was purchased from the shop of the appellant was the very same butter which was sent to the Public Analyst and also for the reason that butter prepared out of curd did not come within the mischief of the definition of the word butter in rule A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955

facts.text: Magistrate acquitted because butter prepared out of curd did not come within definition of butter in rule A.11.05.

anchor.surface_text: and also for the reason that butter prepared out of curd did not come within the mischief of the definition of the word butter in rule A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955 hereinafter called the Rules . The Food Inspector preferred an appeal against that order of acquittal to the High Court.

facts.text: Food Inspector preferred appeal against acquittal to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Food Inspector preferred an appeal against that order of acquittal to the High Court. The High Court held that the conclusion of the learned Judicial Magistrate that the butter purchased from the appellant might have been tampered with before it was sent to the Public Analyst was not based on any evidence on the record.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed the appeal, set aside acquittal, convicted appellant u/s 16 r/w s.7(1), sentenced to RI 2 months and fine Rs. 250/-

anchor.surface_text: In the result it set aside the order of acquittal, convicted the appellant under the Act and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for two months and to pay a fine of Rs. 250/-. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: High Court held that Magistrate's conclusion on tampering not based on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the conclusion of the learned Judicial Magistrate that the butter purchased from the appellant might have been tampered with before it was sent to the Public Analyst was not based on any evidence on the record. It further held that butter prepared from curds was covered by the definition of the word butter given in the relevant rule.

facts.text: High Court held butter prepared from curds covered by definition in rule A.11.05.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that butter prepared from curds was covered by the definition of the word butter given in the relevant rule. It further held that- even if the butter prepared out of curds was not butter as defined in the said rule, the appellant would still be liable under s. 2 (i)(a) of the Act as it contained foreign fat and, therefore, was an adulterated article of food within the meaning of the said section.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that butter prepared from curd comes within definition of butter in r. A.11.05.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that butter prepared from curd comes within the definition of butter in r. A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Rules. The second contention turns upon a question of fact. The High Court considered the entire evidence and accepting the evidence of the Food Inspector and the Health Officer, held that the bottle sent to the Public Analyst was the sample seized from the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts High Court finding that bottle sent to Public Analyst was the sample seized from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered the entire evidence and accepting the evidence of the Food Inspector and the Health Officer, held that the bottle sent to the Public Analyst was the sample seized from the appellant. There are no permissible grounds for allowing the appellant to canvass the correctness of this finding. We, therefore, accept the finding.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Public Analyst report not vague; foreign fat 18.32% is of the butter fat.

anchor.surface_text: The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule. If so, it follows that the appellant is guilty of the offence with which he was charged.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside sentence of RI 2 months and fine Rs 250, imposes fine of Rs 500/- instead.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.

facts.text: On April 16, 1960, Central Government amended rule A-11.05 by inserting 'curd' in definition of butter.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, it was brought to our notice, that on April 16, 1960, the Central Government made another rule amending rule A-11.05 by inserting the word curd in the definition of butter and the amended definition reads, butter means the product prepared exclusively from milk, cream or. curd of cow or buffalo

facts.text: In India butter is prepared in rural areas by indigenous process out of soured milk and cream i.e. curd.

anchor.surface_text: In India butter is prepared in the rural areas by the indigenous process out of soured milk and cream, i.e., curd. In some cities butter is also made directly out of milk and cream but the percentage of the said production is insignificant compared with the indigenous system obtaining throughout India.

facts.text: Rule A.11.05 defines butter as product prepared exclusively from milk or cream of cow or buffalo, or both, containing not less than 80% milk fat, not more than 16% moisture, no preservative.

anchor.surface_text: Rule A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Rules defines butter to mean the product prepared exclusively from the milk or cream of cow or buffalo, or both, or without the addition of salt and annatto and shall contain not less than 80 per cent. of milk fat and not more than 16 per cent. of moisture and no preservative is permissible in butter.

arguments.claim: The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule

anchor.surface_text: The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule. If so, it follows that the appellant is guilty of the offence with which he was charged.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that butter prepared from curd comes within the definition of butter in r. A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion we have arrived at is not only supported by the plain words of the rule, but also carries out the clear intention of the Legislature. The Act was passed to make provisions for the prevention of adulteration of food. Butter is a favourite edible fat and is consumed in different ways by innumerable persons in this country. As we have already pointed out, butter is prepared in the rural areas throughout this country by the indigenous process of churning soured milk, whereas only in a few cities butter is prepared directly from milk. The interpretation suggested by learned counsel for the appellant, if accepted, would make the rule a dead- letter, for all practical purposes, and the object of the Legislature would be defeated. In our view, the intention of the Legislature has been clearly expressed in the rule. We, therefore, hold that butter prepared from curd comes within the definition of butter in r. A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language 'prepared exclusively from milk or cream' includes butter from curd as curd is soured milk/cream; separate definitions for milk, cream, curd serve commercial distinction not exclusion; 'exclusively' limits to cow/buffalo milk; strict construction of penal rule yields inclusion per plain meaning; agrees with Sadashiv full bench overruling Narshinha; purposive to prevent adulteration.

holdings.text: There are no permissible grounds for allowing the appellant to canvass the correctness of this finding. We, therefore, accept the finding.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention turns upon a question of fact. The High Court considered the entire evidence and accepting the evidence of the Food Inspector and the Health Officer, held that the bottle sent to the Public Analyst was the sample seized from the appellant. There are no permissible grounds for allowing the appellant to canvass the correctness of this finding. We, therefore, accept the finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding on fact after reviewing evidence of Food Inspector and Health Officer; no grounds in special leave appeal to interfere with concurrent factual finding.

holdings.text: The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule. If so, it follows that the appellant is guilty of the offence with which he was charged.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention is that the report of the Public Analyst is ambiguous and, therefore, the benefit of doubt should be given to the appellant. What is stated is that in the report it is stated that the butter contained 19.57 of moisture, 64.67 of milk fat and 18.32 of foreign fat, totalling 102.56 i.e., more than 100. It is, therefore, argued that the report on the face of it is incorrect and therefore should not be acted upon. There is an obvious fallacy underlying this argument. 18.32 per cent. of foreign fat is not a percentage in relation to the milk but only in relation to the fat Out of the fat in the milk,. the analyst says that 18.32 per cent. is foreign fat. In his own words, The butter fat in the sample contains 18.32 foreign fat. If that be so, there is no mistake on the face of the report. The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Foreign fat percentage relates to butter fat not total weight; moisture exceeds 16%, milk fat below 80%; report unambiguous.

holdings.text: We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

anchor.surface_text: The High Court sentenced the accused to undergo rigorous imprisonment for two months and also to pay a fine of Rs. 250/-. We agree with the High Court that the offence committed by the appellant is a serious one and that ordinarily the punishment should be deterrent. In most of the cases of this kind imprisonment would certainly be a suitable sentence. But in this case, there was a conflict of view even, in the Bombay High Court as regards the question whether butter made from curd would be butter within the meaning of the rule. Indeed, it was brought to our notice, that on April 16, 1960, the Central Government made another rule amending rule A-11.05 by inserting the word curd in the definition of butter and the amended definition.reads, butter means the product prepared exclusively from milk, cream or. curd of cow or buffalo This must have been made to clarify the position in view of the conflicting decisions. In the circumstances, we think that a sentence of fine would meet the ends, of justice in the present case. We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence serious warranting deterrent; but prior conflict in High Court and subsequent rule amendment inserting 'curd' justify reducing to fine only.

anchor.surface_text: Newby v. Sims 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Acts against adulteration do not require stricter construction merely because they impose penalties
precedents.cited_holding: I cannot concur in the contention that because these acts against adulteration impose penalties, therefore, their construction should, necessarily, be strict. I think that neither greater nor less strictness should be applied to those than to other statutes.

precedents.citation: Narshinha Bhaskar v. State of Bombay 2

precedents.case_name: Narshinha Bhaskar v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Butter prepared from curd does not fall within the definition of butter under rule A.11.05

anchor.surface_text: Sadashiv v. P. V. Bhalerao

precedents.cited_proposition: Butter prepared from dahi or curd is butter prepared from milk, as the emphasis is on the basic material from which butter is prepared and not on the process
precedents.cited_holding: The emphasis is, therefore, on the basic material from which butter is prepared and not on the process by which it is made. Dahi is prepared from milk by souring it. Butter prepared from Dahi can, therefore, be said to be butter prepared from milk itself...

anchor.surface_text: Hunt v. Richardson 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Selling milk below the prescribed standard of milk fat does not constitute an offence if the deficiency is not due to abstraction of fat or addition of water
precedents.cited_holding: This section does not authorize the Board of Agriculture to define what is milk, or to fix a standard... the regulation providing that where a sample of milk contains less than 3 per cent. of milk fat it shall be presumed... that it may be proved to be genuine although it contains less than 3 per cent. of milk fat.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction under s.16 read with s.7 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act upheld; High Court sentence of 2 months rigorous imprisonment and Rs.250 fine set aside and replaced with fine of Rs.500/- only
directions: set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/-
sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion we have arrived at is not only supported by the plain words of the rule, but also carries out the clear intention of the Legislature. The Act was passed to make provisions for the prevention of adulteration of food. Butter is a favourite edible fat and is consumed in different ways by innumerable persons in this country. As we have already pointed out, butter is prepared in the rural areas throughout this country by the indigenous process of churning soured milk, whereas only in a few cities butter is prepared directly from milk. The interpretation suggested by learned counsel for the appellant, if accepted, would make the rule a dead- letter, for all practical purposes, and the object of the Legislature would be defeated. In our view, the intention of the Legislature has been clearly expressed in the rule. We, therefore, hold that butter prepared from curd comes within the definition of butter in r. A.11.05 of Appendix B to the Rules.
until the companytrary was proved, that the milk was number genuine. In exercise of their power, the Board of Agriculture made a r

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.

The second contention turns upon a question of fact. The High Court considered the entire evidence and accepting the evidence of the Food Inspector and the Health Officer, held that the bottle sent to the Public Analyst was the sample seized from the appellant. There are no permissible grounds for allowing the appellant to canvass the correctness of this finding. We, therefore, accept the finding.
We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.

The last contention is that the report of the Public Analyst is ambiguous and, therefore, the benefit of doubt should be given to the appellant. What is stated is that in the report it is stated that the butter contained 19.57 of moisture, 64.67 of milk fat and 18.32 of foreign fat, totalling 102.56 i.e., more than 100. It is, therefore, argued that the report on the face of it is incorrect and therefore should not be acted upon. There is an obvious fallacy underlying this argument. 18.32 per cent. of foreign fat is not a percentage in relation to the milk but only in relation to the fat Out of the fat in the milk,. the analyst says that 18.32 per cent. is foreign fat. In his own words, The butter fat in the sample contains 18.32 foreign fat. If that be so, there is no mistake on the face of the report. The report clearly indicates that the butter sold by the appellant was below the standard prescribed under the rule.
We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.
We, therefore, set aside the sentence of two months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs 250/- and instead sentence the appellant to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-.
